statement.text: Innominate artery reimplantation involves surgically revascularizing the brachiocephalic trunk either as direct reimplantation during open arch repair or as debranching bypass from ascending aorta prior to endovascular arch coverage.

explanation.intuition: The innominate artery supplies the right arm and right side of the brain. When replacing or covering the aortic arch, you must maintain this blood supply - either by sewing it into the new graft or bypassing it before covering with an endograft.
explanation.key_insight: Zone 0 arch coverage requires innominate revascularization. Hybrid approach uses ascending aortic bypass; total arch replacement uses direct reimplantation with island or separate branches under circulatory arrest.
explanation.technical_details: Approaches: (1) Open total arch - reimplant as island with LCCA/LSCA or as separate anastomoses (branched graft), (2) Hybrid debranching - ascending aorta to innominate bypass (8-10mm Dacron), (3) Extra-anatomic - carotid-carotid bypass with innominate ligation. Circulatory arrest strategies: deep hypothermia, antegrade cerebral perfusion through axillary cannulation. Stroke risk 3-10% with arch procedures.

approaches.open_replacement: Direct reimplantation with island or branched graft under circulatory arrest
approaches.hybrid: Ascending aorta to innominate bypass through median sternotomy

procedural_details.cerebral_protection: Antegrade cerebral perfusion via axillary cannulation

clinical_pearls: Right axillary cannulation provides antegrade cerebral perfusion during arrest
Hybrid debranching avoids circulatory arrest but requires sternotomy
Innominate bypass graft should originate from ascending aorta, not arch
